awd_titl_txt: WoU-MMA: Collaborative Research: A Next-Generation SuperNova Early Warning System for Multimessenger Astronomy
awd_abstract_narration:
When a massive star reaches the end of its life, the core of the star collapses, producing a supernova. While visually spectacular, less than 1% of the energy in the supernova is released as visible light or as kinetic energy in the surrounding environment. Most of the energy from the supernova is carried away by neutrinos produced during the collapse of the core.  In contrast to photons, neutrinos interact only very weakly with matter.  They can therefore stream out of the supernova explosion without delay and thus arrive at Earth minutes to hours before the optical explosion may be visible. Detecting the first neutrinos from a supernova therefore provides an early alert to trigger further observations. The SuperNova Early Warning System (SNEWS) is a network of neutrino detectors around the world designed to provide automated early alerts for supernovae in our galaxy. While rare, a galactic supernova would provide a unique opportunity to study the physics of core-collapse supernova, as well as the properties of neutrinos. Alerts from SNEWS will enable observations of the earliest phases of the supernova for physicists and astronomers around the world. The SNEWS project works to engage amateur astronomers by involving them in this science, as they play an important role in optical observations of supernova.

This award supports a collaborative group from several institutions to upgrade the existing SNEWS real-time alert system to include new detectors, and to prepare to better exploit the collective capabilities of these detectors.  The team will model neutrino light curves and use those models to evaluate the expected signals in all available neutrino detectors.  They will develop optimal methods for prompt determination of the supernova direction using both neutrino interaction anisotropies, as well as inter-experiment triangulation algorithms which will be based on relative observed timing of the neutrino signals.  Prompt directional information will sharply improve the likelihood to detect the early onset of the light curve in multiple channels.  This is crucial not only for the understanding of supernova explosions, but also for many other areas of physics including astrophysics, nuclear physics, and particle physics.  Finally they will develop pre-supernova alerts based on the observation of the uptick in neutrino production that accompanies the final burning stages of a doomed star.  This proposal also supports involvement of the amateur astronomy community in this exciting area  of research, the creation of a topical planetarium show, as well as a smartphone app for use in education and alert dissemination.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Background: The Supernova Neutrino Early Warning System is a network of neutrino detectors that will alert the world of the next supernova associated with the explosion of a massive star in the Milky Way galaxy. Galactic supernovae occur only every 50-100 years, so this is a rare but incredibly important event that demands patience and sophisticated coordination to exploit it for the benefit of science and humanity. Because supernova neutrinos will arrive minutes to hours before electromagnetic radiation is observable and will likely be much easier to detect and localize than gravitational waves, SNEWS has the unique responsibility of distributing information about the supernova as rapidly as possible. This way, enormous science-rich opportunities to investigate extreme physics and astrophysics can be capitalized upon. 

Intellectual Merit: SNEWS 2.0 is an upgrade of the original network that has been operating since 2005. The upgrade is needed to expand the network of participating facilities, provide a means of localization of the neutrino burst, and better connect SNEWS to the wider array of multi-messenger facilities that are now available. Purdue is one of many worldwide institutions that participates in SNEWS and has multiple roles. For the duration of this grant, Purdue led the SNEWS 2.0 effort. At the heart of the SNEWS2.0 network is a coincidence server that Purdue helps to operate. Purdue is also a neutrino facility participant through its membership in the XENON1T experiment that seeks to directly detect dark matter candidates using liquid xenon. Purdue also leads the effort to design the multi-messenger global follow-up coordination necessary to most efficiently identify and monitor the star that is exploding. This follow up includes how to best crowdsource the world’s supply of telescopes (professional and amateur) to enable the first precise measurement of the time it takes the core collapse bounce shock to travel through the star and emerge from its surface.

Broader Impacts: Outreach to the scientific community, to amateur astronomers, and to the general public are crucial and intricate parts of the SNEWS effort. Collaboration members regularly give public talks about supernova explosions at local clubs and are interviewed for popular press articles and broadcast news. The collaboration has formed a strong connection with the American Association of Variable Star Observers who have developed a special program to monitor hundreds of stars that are likely to explode as supernovae. A subset of these observers also participate in the follow-up response network. We created a new website snews2.org that serves as an information resource for professionals and the general public. A mobile app was developed for the iPhone that notifies users of SNEWS alerts and provides a discussion board to ask questions. Finally, in collaboration with planetarium experts in Europe, we produced a planetarium show about the origins of humanity that is available to planetariums world-wide free of charge.
